facts.text: Appellant Bhagwan Singh convicted of murder of Buggar Singh and sentenced to death; also convicted under section 19 of Indian Arms Act.

Deceased had fired at appellant's brother six or seven years before, sent to jail; police took proceedings under section 107 CrPC binding down appellant's two brothers, cousins, and deceased; constituted motive proved by Bhag Singh PW7.
On 7th September 1950, about 12-15 p.m., appellant sitting at shop of Jit Singh PW2; deceased came, borrowed Rs.5 from Jit Singh, entered in account book.
Deceased left shop, followed by appellant who shot him at point blank range with pistol, 4 or 5 karams from shop.
Bystanders chased appellant, apprehended after short run of 30 karams; still carrying pistol taken by Jagir Singh Patwari PW4.
Appellant taken to local police post 100 karams away; Jit Singh PW2 made first information report at 12-27 p.m., within 15 minutes.
Occurrence witnessed by large number; prosecution examined five: two turned hostile in Sessions Court, one neutral per High Court; Balbir Singh PW5 and Jaswant Singh PW6 believed.
Jaswant Singh PW6 not examined by Committing Magistrate as he was unavailable.
Jit Singh PW2 supported prosecution in chief but resiled in cross; treated hostile, cross-examined; admitted Committal statement tallying with chief and FIR.
Jagir Singh PW4 hostile from start; formalities of s.145 Evidence Act complied with in cross-examination.
Jit Singh PW2 and Jagir Singh PW4 claimed statements before Committing Magistrate not read over and made under police threats/duress.
Appellant represented by two counsel in Sessions Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the conviction can be rested on the testimony of Balbir Singh PW5 and Jaswant Singh PW6.
Whether Jaswant Singh PW6 not examined by Committing Magistrate makes his Sessions Court evidence inadmissible.

Whether irregularities in trial, including under Chapter XVIII CrPC s.208, s.540, s.537, use of prior statements without s.288 formalities, non-compliance with s.145 Evidence Act, statements not read over per s.360 CrPC, made under duress, and s.342 CrPC, vitiate the trial.

petitioner_arguments.text: Evidence of Jaswant Singh PW6 inadmissible as not examined by Committing Magistrate; raises issue under s.208 CrPC; s.540 not applicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC ss.208, 540; Sher Bahadur v. The Crown

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court used Committal statements of Jit Singh PW2 and Jagir Singh PW4 as substantive evidence without s.288 CrPC formalities.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC s.288; Tara Singh v. The State; Evidence Act s.145

petitioner_arguments.text: For Jit Singh PW2, prior statement used without s.145 compliance as not confronted properly.
For Jagir Singh PW4, attention not drawn to specific parts of writing for contradiction per s.145.
Committal depositions not read over to witnesses; certificate under s.80 Evidence Act displaced without enquiry.
Witness statements before Committing Magistrate under police threats/duress; requires enquiry.
No proper compliance with s.342 CrPC.

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution story as per FIR and eyewitnesses; motive proved; appellant apprehended on spot with pistol.

court_reasoning.text: Jaswant Singh PW6 not examined by Magistrate due to unavailability; Sessions Court power under s.540 CrPC; examined by counsel is irregularity curable by s.537; no objection at trial; no prejudice as named in FIR and calendar, statement presumably available under s.162.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No prejudice; too late to object.

court_reasoning.text: High Court believed PW5 and PW6; PW2 and PW4 prior statements used as corroboration under s.157 Evidence Act, not substantive without s.288; witness admitted prior statement, no need for s.145 confrontation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Substantive evidence is chief examination corroborated by prior consistent statement.

court_reasoning.text: For PW4, s.145 complied substantially; questioned point by point, whole short statement read and admitted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Matter of substance, not form; fair opportunity given.

court_reasoning.text: s.80 Evidence Act presumes certificate correct; burden on appellant to displace, no duty to enquire; even if not read over, curable irregularity without prejudice shown by affidavit.
Allegations of threats/duress collateral; burden on appellant, evidence not believed; no roving enquiry.
Substantial compliance with s.342 CrPC; no prejudice shown or answers disclosed.
Appellant caught red-handed with pistol; FIR within 15 min; simple case.

holdings.text: Testimony of PW5 and PW6 reliable for conviction.
Omission to examine PW6 before Committing Magistrate curable under s.540, s.537 CrPC; no prejudice.
All trial irregularities venial, curable, no prejudice; prior statements properly used as corroboration.

precedents_cited.relevance: Omission curable; decided on prejudice, conceded s.540 power.
Issue of refusal to examine not applicable.
Against contention that unexamined witness inadmissible.
Against contention that unexamined witness inadmissible.
Magistrate refused examination and prevented cross; not applicable.
No two versions; hostile from start, pure contradiction case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kashmira Singh v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Undesirability of examining Magistrate on certificate.
Undesirability of examining Magistrate on certificate.
Not reading over is curable without prejudice shown by affidavit.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Arms Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction thereunder, not concerned in appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Bindings, trial irregularities curable; power to examine witnesses; prior statements substantive.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption on certificate; confrontation for contradiction; corroboration by prior statement.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction for murder and death sentence affirmed; all technical objections rejected as irregularities curable without prejudice.

key_quotes.text: This is a simple case though it was argued at great length on behalf of the appellant and a number of technical objections to the validity of the trial taken.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Summarizes nature of case and dismisses technicalities.

key_quotes.text: The case is a very simple one in which a man was caught red-handed with a pistol still in his hand and in which the first information report was recorded practically on the spot within 15 minutes of the occurrence.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Corroboration is as useful to test the truth of a story as any other method.
key_quotes.speaker: court
